Question: 1) A 72-year-old man with HTN and COPD presents with 5.6-cm infrarenal AAA discovered on surveillance. He is an active smoker. CTA shows favorable neck (>15 mm length, <60° angulation) and suitable iliac access. Best management?
D: Stop smoking and re-image in 6 months
Explanation: Elective repair threshold is typically ≥5.5 cm in men. With EVAR-favorable anatomy and acceptable risk, EVAR is appropriate.

Question: 2) A 64-year-old woman with 5.1-cm infrarenal AAA on CTA. She is otherwise healthy. Neck is adequate; iliac access is small but passable. She asks about timing.
B: Proceed with EVAR given female threshold
C: Open repair only due to sex
Explanation: Women have a lower rupture threshold; many guidelines support elective repair around 5.0 cm in women when risk is acceptable.

Question: 3) A 69-year-old with severe postprandial pain, food fear, and 20-lb weight loss. Duplex shows >70% stenosis of celiac and SMA; IMA occluded. CTA confirms multivessel disease. Best revascularization strategy?
Explanation: SMA is the key target; endovascular-first (angioplasty/stenting) is standard in many centers with good outcomes.

Question: 4) A 58-year-old man with new severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Lactate elevated. CTA shows abrupt SMA occlusion with poor opacification distally. Best initial step?
A: IV heparin and urgent SMA embolectomy/endo-thrombectomy
Explanation: Embolic acute mesenteric ischemia requires prompt anticoagulation and urgent revascularization to salvage bowel.

Question: 5) A 76-year-old with prior EVAR has sac enlargement from 5.6→6.0 cm at 12 months. CTA: contrast filling of sac via lumbar arteries; proximal and distal seals intact. Management?
B: Treat as Type I endoleak with proximal cuff
C: Transarterial or translumbar embolization of feeders (Type II)
Explanation: Type II endoleak from branch retrograde flow is treated when the sac enlarges; embolization of feeding vessels is typical.

Question: 6) A 70-year-old with 80% left ICA stenosis (NASCET) and TIA 1 week ago. He is neurologically intact now. Center has excellent CEA outcomes (<3% periop stroke/death). Next step?
C: Carotid stenting is preferred in all symptomatic patients
Explanation: Symptomatic ≥70% stenosis benefits from early CEA (ideally within 14 days) when perioperative risk is low.

Question: 7) A 74-year-old with left hemispheric TIA and 85% ICA stenosis but prior radical neck dissection and radiation. Which strategy is most appropriate?
Explanation: CAS is an option in high surgical risk or hostile neck anatomy where CEA risk is elevated.

Question: 8) A 62-year-old dialysis patient with hand pain and coolness after AVF creation (brachiocephalic). Exam: delayed capillary refill, diminished radial pulse with dialysis flow. Duplex shows high-flow access, good distal arteries. Best management?
Explanation: Steal syndrome with intact distal runoff is often managed with DRIL to preserve access while restoring hand perfusion.

Question: 9) A 55-year-old runner with exertional calf pain. Ankle-brachial index is normal at rest; drops post-exercise. Duplex: focal SFA lesion in Hunter canal. Preferred therapy after failed supervised exercise/medical therapy?
Explanation: Focal femoropopliteal lesions are typically treated with endovascular-first strategies after conservative therapy fails.

Question: 10) A 67-year-old with blue toe syndrome after recent aortic manipulation. Kidney function worsens. Skin shows livedo reticularis. Diagnosis?
Explanation: Atheroembolism causes blue toes, livedo, eosinophilia, and renal dysfunction after aortic procedures.

Question: 11) A 63-year-old with blunt trauma after MVC. CTA shows focal descending thoracic aortic pseudoaneurysm (BTAI grade II). He is stable. Best management?
Explanation: Most grade II–IV blunt thoracic aortic injuries are treated with TEVAR plus strict BP/HR control.

Question: 12) A 60-year-old man with painful, swollen entire leg and cyanosis. Duplex confirms extensive iliofemoral DVT. Diagnosis is phlegmasia cerulea dolens. Initial management?
B: Immediate therapeutic anticoagulation and urgent consideration of CDT/thrombectomy
Explanation: Phlegmasia threatens limb; anticoagulate urgently and consider catheter-directed therapy/thrombectomy in appropriate centers.

Question: 13) A 47-year-old smoker with migratory superficial thrombophlebitis and distal digital ischemia. Angiography shows segmental occlusions and corkscrew collaterals in tibial arteries. Best long-term management?
Explanation: Buerger disease (TAO) improves only with strict tobacco cessation; other therapies are limited.

Question: 14) A 66-year-old woman with rest pain and tissue loss (heel ulcer). Toe pressure 25 mmHg. Best interpretation and next step?
Explanation: Toe pressure <30–50 mmHg with tissue loss/rest pain supports CLTI; revascularization planning is indicated.
Reference Title: Global Vascular Guidelines on CLTI – Summary

Question: 15) A 59-year-old with infected aortic endograft (fever, back pain). CTA: perigraft gas/fluid. Blood cultures positive. Best management principle?
B: Endograft explantation with extra-anatomic or in situ reconstruction in most cases
Explanation: Proven graft infection generally requires explantation plus durable reconstruction, alongside antibiotics.

Question: 16) A 62-year-old with claudication, focal mid-SFA lesion, normal inflow. After angioplasty he asks about meds. Best antithrombotic plan?
B: Single antiplatelet long-term; brief DAPT may be reasonable post-stent
Explanation: Guidelines favor single antiplatelet long-term; short DAPT considered after certain endovascular interventions.

Question: 17) A 70-year-old with carotid endarterectomy yesterday now has hoarseness. First test?
B: Laryngoscopy to assess vocal cord motion
Explanation: Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is a known risk; laryngoscopy documents cord motion and guides therapy.

Question: 18) A 63-year-old woman with pulsatile popliteal mass and mural thrombus on duplex (28 mm). She has embolic toe ischemia. Best management?
Explanation: Symptomatic PAA (thromboembolism) warrants repair to prevent limb-threatening events.

Question: 19) A 65-year-old with suspected subclavian steal: dizziness with left arm exertion; left radial pulse diminished. Best initial diagnostic test?
B: Duplex with vertebral artery flow assessment
Explanation: Retrograde vertebral flow on duplex supports subclavian steal; cross-sectional imaging defines anatomy for intervention.

Question: 20) A 68-year-old with painful, enlarging groin mass 2 weeks after femoral puncture. Duplex shows yin-yang sign. Management of femoral pseudoaneurysm 2.5 cm with narrow neck?
Explanation: UGTI is effective for suitable iatrogenic femoral pseudoaneurysms with a narrow neck and is first-line in many centers.

Question: 21) A 58-year-old with exertional arm swelling and cyanosis after rowing. Duplex: non-compressible axillosubclavian vein; venogram shows dynamic compression at first rib. Diagnosis and management?
B: Venous TOS (Paget–Schroetter); thrombolysis ± first rib resection
Explanation: Effort thrombosis (venous TOS) often managed with thrombolysis, decompression (first rib) to prevent recurrence.

Question: 22) A 35-year-old with sudden calf claudication. Duplex suggests popliteal artery entrapment. Imaging shows medial head gastrocnemius anomaly contacting artery. Next step?
Explanation: PAES requires decompression of anomalous muscle; reconstruction if fixed arterial damage exists.

Question: 23) A 74-year-old with 6.4-cm arch aneurysm. Bicuspid aortic valve and family history of aortopathy. Threshold for elective repair is generally:
Explanation: Certain conditions (bicuspid valve, heritable thoracic aortic disease) lower thresholds vs sporadic 5.5 cm.

Question: 24) A 67-year-old after EVAR now has sac growth with NO visible endoleak on CTA. Diagnosis?
Explanation: Endotension is aneurysm sac enlargement without demonstrable endoleak; management individualized.

Question: 25) A 71-year-old with critical limb-threatening ischemia and tissue loss at forefoot. Vein mapping shows usable great saphenous vein. Best conduit for infrainguinal bypass?
Explanation: GSV has superior patency/limb salvage for infrainguinal bypass when available.

Question: 26) A 62-year-old on heparin develops platelets 60k and new DVT. 4T score high. Next step?
B: Stop heparin; start argatroban or other non-heparin anticoagulant
Explanation: Acute HIT requires stopping heparin and initiating a non-heparin anticoagulant; avoid warfarin initially.

Question: 27) An asymptomatic 68-year-old man (40 pack-years) asks about AAA screening. Best recommendation?
Explanation: USPSTF-style guidance supports one-time US screening in men 65–75 who have ever smoked.

Question: 28) A 73-year-old woman with severe carotid restenosis after CAS by duplex (high PSV/EDV using lab’s post-stent criteria). She is asymptomatic. Best next step?
B: Confirm with CTA/MRA and consider re-intervention depending on severity/risk
Explanation: Post-stent duplex criteria differ; confirm severity with imaging and consider re-intervention selectively.

Question: 29) A 59-year-old with groin puncture site swelling and fever after PCI. Duplex shows pseudoaneurysm with surrounding fluid; blood cultures positive. Best management?
C: Surgical repair and debridement with antibiotics
Explanation: Infected pseudoaneurysm requires open debridement/repair plus antibiotics; UGTI is contraindicated.

Question: 30) A 63-year-old with chronic venous insufficiency and medial gaiter area ulcer. Best diagnostic to assess reflux?
Explanation: Venous duplex with reflux assessment evaluates valve incompetence and guides intervention.

Question: 31) A 68-year-old with rest pain and toe gangrene. CTA shows long-segment SFA occlusion and poor tibial runoff; common femoral inflow is adequate. Best revascularization approach?
B: Fem-pop bypass to the best target using great saphenous vein
Explanation: For complex femoropopliteal disease with tissue loss and usable conduit, autogenous vein bypass offers better durability.

Question: 32) A 61-year-old post-CEA day 1 has neck swelling and airway deviation. Saturations falling. Next step?
Explanation: Expanding hematoma threatening airway after CEA is a surgical emergency; decompress immediately.

Question: 33) A 70-year-old with infected femoral PTFE bypass graft (purulence, exposed graft). Blood cultures pending. Best management?
B: Explant infected graft and perform extra-anatomic bypass if needed
Explanation: Infected prosthetic grafts usually require removal with revascularization via clean field as needed.

Question: 34) A 65-year-old with acute limb ischemia: mottled foot, no motor/sensory deficits; audible arterial Doppler signals diminished. Rutherford class?
Explanation: IIa: marginally threatened—no immediate motor weakness; urgent imaging/endovascular therapy reasonable.

Question: 35) A 58-year-old with renovascular HTN and CKD stage 3. Suspected atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis. Best initial imaging?
Explanation: Duplex avoids contrast load and is suitable initial test; CTA/MRA chosen selectively by renal function.

Question: 36) A 54-year-old with exertional posterior calf pain; duplex shows normal arteries but popliteal cyst compressing artery; MRI confirms adventitial cystic disease. Management?
Explanation: Definitive management is surgical excision; bypass/patch if arterial wall compromised.

Question: 37) A 72-year-old with recurrent toe ulcer after fem-pop PTFE bypass 2 years ago. Duplex shows low graft velocities and elevated inflow iliac velocities. Next step?
Explanation: Graft surveillance aims to detect inflow/outflow lesions; treat inflow iliac stenosis to optimize graft flow.

Question: 38) A 60-year-old with severe buttock claudication and impotence. Femoral pulses diminished bilaterally. Most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Leriche triad: buttock/thigh claudication, impotence, diminished femoral pulses.

Question: 39) A 67-year-old with suspected mycotic aneurysm (fever, bacteremia, focal arterial pain). Best imaging?
Explanation: CTA defines extent and surrounding inflammation; guides surgery and antibiotics.

Question: 40) A 71-year-old with symptomatic iliac stenosis and disabling claudication after optimal medical therapy. Best intervention?
Explanation: Iliac occlusive lesions respond well to endovascular angioplasty/stenting with excellent patency.

Question: 41) A 62-year-old with diabetic foot infection and gas in tissues. ABI 0.6, toe pressure 30 mmHg. Best sequence?
Explanation: In limb-threatening infection with ischemia, control sepsis and plan prompt revascularization to enable healing.

Question: 42) A 59-year-old with symptomatic ICA stenosis 60% and disabling COPD with poor neck extension. Center has low CAS stroke rates. Best approach?
B: Consider CAS due to prohibitive surgical risk
Explanation: CAS can be considered in high-surgical-risk anatomy/physiology at experienced centers.

Question: 43) A 66-year-old s/p TEVAR for type B dissection presents with persistent hypertension and back pain. CTA shows type I endoleak at proximal seal. Best management?
Explanation: Type I endoleak is high-pressure; treat with seal extension or adjuncts to prevent rupture.

Question: 44) A 71-year-old with recurrent foot ulcer after prior tibial angioplasty; duplex shows single-vessel peroneal runoff. Best revascularization concept?
Explanation: Target vessel selection may follow angiosome concepts to enhance wound healing when feasible.

Question: 45) A 55-year-old with acute painful swollen leg after long flight; ultrasound shows femoral DVT. Low bleeding risk. Best treatment?
Explanation: Most proximal DVTs treated with therapeutic anticoagulation; CDT reserved for select cases.

Question: 46) A 63-year-old with suspected carotid body tumor (Shamblin II) at bifurcation. Preop step?
B: Check for catecholamine secretion when clinically suspected and plan cranial nerve preservation
Explanation: CBTs are paragangliomas; a minority secrete catecholamines—screen when indicated; surgical planning critical.

Question: 47) A 70-year-old with type B aortic dissection managed medically. Targets for anti-impulse therapy?
Explanation: Lower HR and SBP reduce shear stress and complications in uncomplicated type B dissection.

Question: 48) A 65-year-old with infected PTFE fem-pop bypass presents with bleeding at graft site. Concern for blowout. Immediate action?
B: Direct pressure, urgent OR for control and definitive management
Explanation: Threatened hemorrhage from infected graft requires emergent operative control and reconstruction planning.

Question: 49) A 74-year-old with asymptomatic 55% ICA stenosis on duplex (lab criteria). Optimal management?
Explanation: Moderate asymptomatic stenosis is treated with medical therapy and surveillance; intervene if progression/symptoms.

Question: 50) A 60-year-old with suspected splenic artery aneurysm (2.4 cm) and desires future pregnancy. Best management?
B: Endovascular coil/plug or covered stent repair
Explanation: Repair is recommended for >2 cm or in women of childbearing age due to rupture risk.

Question: 51) A 67-year-old with fem-fem bypass for unilateral iliac occlusion now has low graft velocities and CFA inflow stenosis on duplex. Next step?
B: Treat inflow lesion to improve graft patency
Explanation: Patency depends on adequate inflow/outflow; treat CFA/iliac lesions to optimize.

Question: 52) A 59-year-old with resting pain and ABI 0.35. Toe pressure 22 mmHg. Transcutaneous oxygen 20 mmHg at forefoot. Interpretation?
Explanation: Objective hemodynamics meet CLTI thresholds—revascularization should be planned.

Question: 53) A 73-year-old after EVAR has persistent Type I endoleak at distal seal despite ballooning. Next option?
B: Distal extension with limb and/or endoanchors
Explanation: Type I is high-pressure; extension cuffs or adjuncts like endoanchors may be used to obtain seal.

Question: 54) A 65-year-old smoker with recurrent TIAs and near-occlusion (“string sign”) of ICA on CTA. Best management?
B: Consider CEA at experienced center after risk/benefit discussion
Explanation: Select patients with near-occlusion and recurrent symptoms may benefit from CEA in expert hands.

Question: 55) A 50-year-old with trauma to thigh; CTA shows active extravasation from profunda femoris branch. He is stable. Best management?
Explanation: Select arterial hemorrhage in stable trauma patients is treated successfully with endovascular embolization.

Question: 56) A 63-year-old with recurrent calf claudication after prior SFA stent. Duplex shows in-stent restenosis (PSV >300 cm/s). Next step?
Explanation: In-stent restenosis can be treated endovascularly (e.g., DCB, additional stenting) depending on lesion.

Question: 57) A 72-year-old with pulmonary disease and 6.0-cm infrarenal AAA; neck is short and angulated. EVAR would require fenestrated device. Best plan?
B: Consider fenestrated EVAR at experienced center
Explanation: Complex necks may be treated with fenestrated/branched devices at experienced centers.

Question: 58) A 68-year-old with graft limb occlusion after EVAR presenting with acute limb ischemia. Best initial management?
B: Systemic heparin and prompt thrombectomy/stent relining as indicated
Explanation: Graft limb thrombosis requires anticoagulation and urgent reintervention to restore perfusion.

Question: 59) A 66-year-old with symptomatic venous reflux after GSV ablation last year; now has SSV reflux and perforator incompetence at ulcer bed. Best next step?
B: Targeted treatment of refluxing SSV/perforator and compression
Explanation: Ongoing reflux in other segments/perforators may need targeted treatment plus compression to heal ulcers.

Question: 60) A 70-year-old with severe iliac occlusive disease and concomitant small infrarenal AAA (4.8 cm). She is symptomatic from inflow disease. Best approach?
A: Ignore iliac disease until AAA ≥5.5 cm
B: Endovascular iliac revascularization now; surveil AAA
C: Open aortobifem with AAA repair only
Explanation: Treat symptomatic inflow disease endovascularly and continue AAA surveillance until threshold for repair.
Reference Title: PAD and AAA – Combined Management Principles
